Award.AwardTitle: Doctoral Dissertation Research: Stability and Trait-based Predictors of Eyewitness Performance

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Divn Of Social and Economic Sciences

Award.AbstractNarration:
Are witnesses who are accurate at identifying a suspect?s face in a lineup consistently accurate at identifying suspects or in saying what happened during a crime? Given that erroneous eyewitness testimony contributes to wrongful convictions and that jurors give great weight to eyewitness testimony, knowing whether witness accuracy is stable would be helpful. Traditional eyewitness research does not answer these questions, as most studies examine eyewitness memory for only a single witnessed event. Thus, this project seeks to investigate: (1) the stability of witness memory performance, both within and across witness tasks (e.g., lineups, witness reports of criminal events, and resistance to misinformation) and (2) the strength of a number of individual difference variables, including personality and cognitive traits, in predicting eyewitness performance.

The project will examine the stability of witness accuracy both within and across witness accuracy tasks (lineup identification accuracy; accurate memory of the events; and resistance to misleading post-event information about the events) for five brief witnessed events across multiple study sessions. The use of repeated witness tasks for five separate witness events will permit a more sensitive, more generalizable measure of witness accuracy than in prior research.

The stability of witness accuracy has important broader impacts for decision makers (e.g., jurors, prosecutors, police officers, etc.) in the criminal justice system in evaluating the probable accuracy of witness statements or conflicting statements of different witnesses, given that real world witnesses need to be accurate in both their identifications and their event reports regarding a crime. Further, the proposed procedure may provide a new paradigm for investigating witness accuracy. The project will also support the training of a graduate student and expose undergraduate research assistants to the research process.

Institution.Name: University of Nebraska-Lincoln
Institution.ORG_LGL_BUS_NAME: BOARD OF REGENTS OF THE UNIVERSITY OF NEBRASKA

ProgramReference.Text: EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES

POR.DRECONTENT:
Jurors give great weight to eyewitness testimony, and erroneous eyewitness testimony has frequently contributed to wrongful convictions. The stability of witness accuracy is theoretically important because of its implications for the debate over whether memory is a unitary phenomenon or consists of relatively independent subcomponents. The issue also has important broader impacts for decision makers (e.g., jurors, prosecutors, police officers) in the criminal justice system in evaluating the probable accuracy of witness identifications and statements, given that real world witnesses need to be accurate in both their identifications and their event reports regarding a crime. Most traditional eyewitness research does not address the issue of the stability of eyewitness performance, as most studies have examined eyewitness memory for only a single witnessed event and for a single witness task (either lineup performance or event memory performance). Thus, this three-session study explored to what degree eyewitness performance might exhibit stability both within and across lineup and event memory tasks for five separate videos of witness events. The use of repeated witness tasks for five separate witness events was designed to engender a more sensitive, more generalizable measure of witness accuracy than in prior research.  

Lineup Accuracy. Target present lineup responses were scored and summed to generate a total identification accuracy measure (the total number of lineups where the suspect was correctly identified) and a total misidentification measure (the total number of lineups in which the witness incorrectly chose a person other than the criminal from the lineup). Overall, only approximately 10% of the participants made no misidentifications across all 5 lineups. No witness correctly identified the criminal in all 5 lineups, yet approximately 15% of participants accurately identified the criminal on at least 3 of the 5 lineups, which is a level well above chance. More than half of the participants correctly identified only 1 or 2 of the criminals across the 5 lineups, indicating that most witnesses' performance is highly variable. Most notably, approximately a quarter of participants failed to identify the criminal on all 5 of the lineups, demonstrating a consistently error prone witness group. Just under half of this habitually error prone group erroneously identified someone other than the criminal in at least 4 of the 5 lineups (80% of the time). That some individuals consistently chose an incorrect person in repeated lineups is of importance, because this group likely poses the most problems for the legal system. Overall, there do seem to be subsets of individuals with relatively stable lineup accuracy. 

Event Accuracy. After completing each lineup task, participants also completed a series of multiple choice items testing their memory of the corresponding criminal event video. After watching the videos but before the lineups and event tests, participants were presented with some post-event information about the events in the videos, some of which was consistent with what had occurred in the videos (generating consistent items) and some of which was inconsistent or misleading with regard to what had occurred (generating misinformation items); some of the items tested information about which no post-event information had been provided (independent items). Overall, participants displayed moderately low event accuracy for independent items, and moderately high event accuracy for items about matters for which consistent post-event information had been provided. Most participants selected the misinformation response for just under a third of the items that involved misleading post-event information, suggesting a general resistance to misinformation. There did appear to be relationships between performance ...
POR.POR_COPY_TXT: Jurors give great weight to eyewitness testimony, and erroneous eyewitness testimony has frequently contributed to wrongful convictions. The stability of witness accuracy is theoretically important because of its implications for the debate over whether memory is a unitary phenomenon or consists of relatively independent subcomponents. The issue also has important broader impacts for decision makers (e.g., jurors, prosecutors, police officers) in the criminal justice system in evaluating the probable accuracy of witness identifications and statements, given that real world witnesses need to be accurate in both their identifications and their event reports regarding a crime. Most traditional eyewitness research does not address the issue of the stability of eyewitness performance, as most studies have examined eyewitness memory for only a single witnessed event and for a single witness task (either lineup performance or event memory performance). Thus, this three-session study explored to what degree eyewitness performance might exhibit stability both within and across lineup and event memory tasks for five separate videos of witness events. The use of repeated witness tasks for five separate witness events was designed to engender a more sensitive, more generalizable measure of witness accuracy than in prior research. Lineup Accuracy. Target present lineup responses were scored and summed to generate a total identification accuracy measure (the total number of lineups where the suspect was correctly identified) and a total misidentification measure (the total number of lineups in which the witness incorrectly chose a person other than the criminal from the lineup). Overall, only approximately 10% of the participants made no misidentifications across all 5 lineups. No witness correctly identified the criminal in all 5 lineups, yet approximately 15% of participants accurately identified the criminal on at least 3 of the 5 lineups, which is a level well above chance. More than half of the participants correctly identified only 1 or 2 of the criminals across the 5 lineups, indicating that most witnesses' performance is highly variable. Most notably, approximately a quarter of participants failed to identify the criminal on all 5 of the lineups, demonstrating a consistently error prone witness group. Just under half of this habitually error prone group erroneously identified someone other than the criminal in at least 4 of the 5 lineups (80% of the time). That some individuals consistently chose an incorrect person in repeated lineups is of importance, because this group likely poses the most problems for the legal system. Overall, there do seem to be subsets of individuals with relatively stable lineup accuracy. Event Accuracy. After completing each lineup task, participants also completed a series of multiple choice items testing their memory of the corresponding criminal event video. After watching the videos but before the lineups and event tests, participants were presented with some post-event information about the events in the videos, some of which was consistent with what had occurred in the videos (generating consistent items) and some of which was inconsistent or misleading with regard to what had occurred (generating misinformation items); some of the items tested information about which no post-event information had been provided (independent items). Overall, participants displayed moderately low event accuracy for independent items, and moderately high event accuracy for items about matters for which consistent post-event information had been provided. Most participants selected the misinformation response for just under a third of the items that involved misleading post-event information, suggesting a general resistance to misinformation. There did appear to be relationships between performance on the different types of event memory tasks, suggesting some stability in performance across these tasks. Specificall...
